body:
**If this issue affects you, please react with a ðŸ‘ (thumbs up emoji) to the initial post.**

Your feedback helps us prioritize which bugs to investigate and address first.

![Visits](https://hits.seeyoufarm.com/api/count/incr/badge.svg?url=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fstreamlit%2Fstreamlit%2Fissues%2F9365&title=visits&edge_flat=false)

rename.from: Custom components do not render on korean Windows
rename.to: Custom components do not render on Korean Windows

body:
Hey @t0mdavid-m, thanks for reporting the issue! It's probably going to be difficult for us to reproduce the issue.

Though I am wondering whether this is something you can catch on the user-side. [Here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5974585/python-not-able-to-open-file-with-non-english-characters-in-path) is a StackOverflow article I have just skimmed through that might be related as well.
It could be interesting to print out the different values of `parent_dir`, `build_dir` in the program and compare them to the actual path.

Thank you for the quick reply!

We printed both variables to console but they look normal:
`parent_dir=C:\Users\qlcsk\Downloads\OpenMS-App (1)\OpenMS-App2\OpenMS-App\src`
`build_dir=C:\Users\qlcsk\Downloads\OpenMS-App (1)\OpenMS-App2\OpenMS-App\src\..\js-component\dist`

So it looks like the issue is not related to korean characters in the filepath.

Interesting! Just to rule it out, could it have something to do with the whitespace character in the name or do you think this confirms the theory about the [backslash issue ](https://github.com/winfsp/winfsp/issues/302) you linked?

On the us version of windows it does work with the whitespace character in the name so I am quite certain that this is not the cause of the issue.

I think it neither confirms or denies the theory of the backslash issue, although I in my opinion that is still the most likely cause. Looking at the normal looking file paths my best guess would be that that the collision of the won sign with the backslash character causes some issue within streamlit.

I have just tried to reproduce it on Windows (Windows Bootcamp on Mac though) and was not able to hit the issue :/ I set the locale in the administration settings to `Korean` and ran an app with an example local custom component similar to your setup and for me it loaded correctly. Perhaps I did something wrong, but the path in the terminal showed the won sign and `locale.getlocale()` indicated that korean was set.

Without being able to reproduce it right now, I cannot really assess next steps. Maybe you or someone else from the community has an idea. I will also float it by the team.

Thanks to floating it by the team and for trying to reproduce the issue. Thus far, I had no luck reproducing the issue myself - it only seems to occur for our korean colleagues. They also just changed their locale to `English (United States)` and the issue still occurs. This might be evidence against the backslash issue.

They are getting the following console log, which is different to what I see when I delete the `index.html` (`404 (Not Found)`):
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d41b35b9-78a9-4a70-ac85-b08ec0fc562c)

Since the exact same component works on my us version of windows I dont believe this error is due to the component. Have you seen a similar error before by any chance or any ideas what might cause this?

No problem ðŸ™‚ 

With the new evidence I am wondering whether reading the file itself [here](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/blob/develop/lib/streamlit/web/server/component_request_handler.py#L56-L57) is the issue or guessing the mimetype [here](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/blob/develop/lib/streamlit/web/server/component_request_handler.py#L67).
What you could try it is modify that path locally in the installed Streamlit package and, for example, hard-code the mimetype to the correct one to see whether that would work and/or add the `encoding='utf8'` argument to the `with open` [call](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/blob/develop/lib/streamlit/web/server/component_request_handler.py#L56) and then restart Streamlit. You should be able to get the path to the streamlit package by executing `python -c "import streamlit as st; print(st.__path__)"` in your terminal. For example, the file to look for would then be for me `/ben/debug/venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/streamlit/web/server/component_request_handler.py`

It turns out that it was completely unrelated to the os being korean. A registry entry set the mime-type of javascript files to `text/plain` causing the browser to refuse execution. I did some research and came up with a solution. I will open a PR soon that avoids this issue (which apparently is not uncommon for windows systems).

issue.title: Determine common mime types by extension

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit â€” A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
## Describe your changes

The mime-type of a file is important for the browser to determine how to render content. For custom components in Streamlit, the mime-type is determined by `mimetypes.guess_type()`, which (skipping over some details) determines the mime type by file extension and a predefined mapping of `file-extension->mime-type`. Furthermore, the configuration of the operating system (for windows that is the registry) is taken into account and given precedent over the predefined mapping in Python.

The registry can in principle be changed by any program and [some programs](https://github.com/golang/go/issues/32350) seem to change the mime-type of javascript files to `text/plain` during installation. This causes an issue for custom components as web browsers refuse to execute javascript files with the mime-type `text/plain` causing custom components not to be rendered. This was the root cause of #9365.

This issue was also discussed by the [Python community](https://bugs.python.org/issue32462). They opted not to fix it as the mime type returned is correct for the given system configuration. Any side effects would be system misconfiguration from their point of view.

For Streamlit, the argument whether it is system misconfiguration or not is not really applicable. The consequence is that custom components are not rendered and thus this is clearly unintended behavior. The changes in this PR determine the mime-type for the three most common web-related file formats (`html`, `js`, and `css`) by file extension alone using a lookup table. For all other formats the mime-type is determined using the previous implementation.

Notable repos with similar approaches:
- the [tensorboard project](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorboard/blob/b9ab24224405d0d7cbbeed4ee2da842f645c364d/tensorboard/program.py#L378-L397) solves the same issue in the same way
- the [azure-cli project](https://github.com/Azure/azure-cli/blob/6322e5868aa50dbc9a71c45b1dc82bdd2e58f9c2/src/azure-cli/azure/cli/command_modules/storage/util.py#L305) also hard-codes the javascript mimetype

## GitHub Issue Link (if applicable)

Fixes #9365 

## Testing Plan

It is hard to come up with a simplistic test case for the cause of the issue as this would require changing the system configuration of the test image.

---

**Contribution License Agreement**

By submitting this pull request you agree that all contributions to this project are made under the Apache 2.0 license.
